title: 108_s2622
content: The Act is titled the "Pecos National Historical Park Land Exchange Act of 2004" and includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act defines key terms such as Federal land, landowner, map, non-Federal land, Park, and Secretaries for the Pecos National Historical Park Land Exchange Act of 2004. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture, acting jointly, define the term "State" as the State of New Mexico. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture, acting jointly, define the term "State" as the State of New Mexico. SEC. 3. LAND EXCHANGE. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture define the term "State" as New Mexico. On conveyance of non-Federal land to the Secretary of the Interior, the Secretary of Agriculture conveys Federal land to the landowner, and the Secretary of the Interior grants an easement for water pipelines to well sites in the Park. The route of the easement is determined in consultation with the landowner. The easement through the Park includes terms and conditions set by the Secretary of the Interior in consultation with the landowner. It must comply with applicable Federal law. Valuation, appraisals, and equalization ensure that the value of Federal and non-Federal land is equal. Appraisals are conducted to determine the value. The Federal and non-Federal land must be appraised by an independent appraiser following specific standards. The appraisals need approval from the Secretaries. If the values of the lands are not equal, they can be equalized. The values of Federal and non-Federal land must be appraised and approved by independent appraisers. If values are not equal, they can be equalized through cash payments or reducing acreage. Cash equalization payments received by the Secretary of Agriculture are deposited in a specific fund. The Sisk Act, also known as Public Law 90-171, allows for the acquisition of land in a State without needing further appropriation. Before the land exchange is completed, an agreement must be made on the costs between the Secretaries and the landowner. The exchange must comply with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 and other relevant laws, including the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. The Secretaries may impose additional terms and conditions for land exchanges to protect U.S. interests. The exchange of Federal and non-Federal land must be completed within 180 days after meeting NEPA requirements and Interior Secretary approval of appraisals. The Secretaries must approve appraisals and agree on costs and terms with the landowner for the land exchange. They are required to notify the Senate and House Committees upon completion of the exchange. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary of the Interior will manage non-Federal land acquired under this Act following National Park System laws. A map must be available for public inspection, and a revised map showing exchanged lands must be submitted to Congress within 180 days. The Secretary of the Interior will manage non-Federal land acquired under this Act following National Park System laws, including the easement described in section 3(b). The Senate passed the Act on October 10, 2004. Attest: EMILY J. REYNOLDS, Secretary.
